cons: Hard to get a job as company values high caliber candidates and qualifications, but still tries to provide opportunities to develop.

job_title: Human Resources Advisor in Plymouth, England
pros: Care, listen & respect their employees & customers. Good focus on doing the right thing & great at consulting with employees. Approachable & supportive. Been absolutely brilliant throughout COVID by showing innovative ways to support health, wellbeing, childcare, furlough.
cons: Benchmarked salaries rather than performance related pay, some people like that . Succession planning needs some work

pros: Good pay, benefits, hours, flex, people, ethos
cons: Difficult to secure a permanent role

job_title: Assistant Housing Officer in Plymouth, England
pros: Working towards improving and strengthening communities within Plymouth, innovative, inclusive and responsive to our customers and staff. Organisation is expanding and it's salary offers are one of the highest paid in Plymouth. Working with our customers to achieve optimum service. Frequent jobs available and secondment opportunities.
cons:
Can be a little too corporate at times, not enough consistency across
The organisation - different depts work so differently.

pros: Almost everyone I worked with was friendly and helpful. The managers I encountered were fair and listened to what I had to say. The working atmosphere in my team was relaxed; we weren't micromanaged. Holiday, flexible working practices, pay, and changing/gym facilities are all better than most other Organisations around Plymouth.
cons: I'm not convinced the 1-2-1s and appraisals were that helpful, I think they could be better designed. Different departments behave in different ways, which sometimes causes conflict. These are only minor issues though.

pros: Good terms and conditions including pay and office environment. Good training opportunities. Staff are committed to giving a good service to tenants.
cons: No advancement opportunities. Teams work in silo's, even in the new building.  Senior staff are way too removed from front line staff, not sure they even know what they do!
